abstract: Make what the food writer Arthur Schwartz calls “the ultimate assimilation crossover food”: Cantonese-style char siu sandwiched between Italian-American garlic bread.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I wrote a column for The Times this week about a sandwich that came out of the borscht-belt Catskills in the 1950s and that still inhabits the menus of diners in Brooklyn and down the south shore of Nassau County on Long Island: thin-sliced, Cantonese-style char siu married to Italian-American garlic bread beneath a veil of sweet-sticky duck sauce. “The ultimate assimilation crossover food” is what the food writer and radio host Arthur Schwartz called it when I interviewed him about it, a taste of illicit exoticism, unkosher and delicious in the extreme.
